feed.title: Ryan P. Randall
feed.subtitle: "Ryan P. Randall's website, with his Ph.D. student and community college librarian blog"

entry.title: August 2020 Monthly Signal Boost
entry.content:
Monthly What?

2020 has not been a kind year. This last month has been hectic and at times very overwhelming. Here‚Äôs some of what has worked to keep my spirits up.

Mindfulness

I‚Äôve been trying to get back into mindfulness & meditation practices, since I‚Äôd like to more skillfully recognize when my mind or emotions wander to realms I‚Äôd prefer they not go. It‚Äôs also good practice at finding joy in small things, to better recharge and practice the hopefulness necessary to keep doing difficult things.

I‚Äôve only listened to the first few practices of the Waking Up app by Sam Harris, but it seems like a great fit for anyone interested in mindfulness practices‚Äîand particularly anyone of a more analytical bent. Tai chi (offered as P.E. classes at UC Riverside!) was the first way I was able to connect with a mindfulness practice in a sustained way. I think this was largely because the slow physical exercises kept my ADHD tendencies occupied just enough to help me also pay attention to my breath, my sensations, and whatever else entered into my attention. Waking Up is the mindfulness instruction I‚Äôve encountered that‚Äôs closest my experience of learning moving mediation though tai chi, largely because of how deftly Harris blends his verbal instructions with periods of silence to help you experience what he presents. I‚Äôm not sure yet if a subscription would be right for me, but I definitely recommend trying the first few (free!) days of the app if you‚Äôve been curious about mindfulness. That‚Äôs especially true if you‚Äôve tried mindfulness previously but were turned off by some aspects how it was taught. Harris‚Äôs approach seems resolutely non-religious and non-spiritual/mystical.

The Plum Village app, on the other hand, clearly centers mindfulness practices in the engaged Buddhist approach of Th√≠ch Nh·∫•t H·∫°nh. The app is entirely free and features guided meditations, other practices, texts, and more from the Plum Village community. If you‚Äôve previously encountered the original version of the app (released back in 2018), the newest versions (up to 2.2 as of mid-August) are greatly expanded and refined. I can‚Äôt speculate what it would be like to learn mindfulness or Buddhist practices primarily through this app, but I definitely appreciate what the Plum Village community has made available through it.

Music

Love Genius by Sonic D has consistently brought a goofy grin to my face since the first time I heard it. It‚Äôs a footwork / bass music version of a Tom Tom Club tune you might recognize through a bunch of songs that sample or remix it‚Äîin particular Mariah Carey‚Äôs ‚ÄúFantasy.‚Äù You might also dig some of his other stuff, such as what he‚Äôs got on Soundcloud or his Math & Science mixes.

Time Flex is basically a compilation of early releases by John Tejada under the moniker Autodidact. Originally released in 1996 & 1997, these tunes have more of a Warp Records / Polygon Window vibe than Tejada‚Äôs later stuff. If you‚Äôve ever wanted something like Polygon Window but with more groove & shuffle, this will be right up your alley.
entry.summary: Mindfulness with the Waking Up and Plum Village apps; Most excellent tunes from Sonic D and Autodidact

entry.title: SIFT Links
entry.content:
Here are some links related to my submission to the ‚Äúinnovative ideas‚Äù lightning talk / virtual poster session of the 2020 MOSS Meetup organized by ICfL.

The SIFT Moves

  • Introducing SIFT, a Four Moves Acronym, Mike Caulfield‚Äôs initial post about the moves
  • Check, Please! Course, an OER textbook with explanations and demonstrations of the moves
  • Caulfield‚Äôs SIFTing through the Pandemic applies the moves to claims about COVID-19

SIFT Moves at CWI

Here‚Äôs a couple components of ‚ÄúSource Sifter,‚Äù a badge in the CWI ‚ÄúResearch Basics Badge Set‚Äù:

  • Evaluating Sources with the SIFT Moves Video
  • SIFT Slides

Related Links

  • Mike Caulfield‚Äôs Web Literacy for Student Fact-Checkers, an OER textbook that predated & lead to the SIFT moves
  • My SIFT vs CRAAP video for instructors at CWI
entry.summary: Links related to a lightning talk for the 2020 MOSS Meetup about our switch from the CRAAP test to the SIFT moves.

entry.title: July 2020 Monthly Signal Boost
entry.content:
Monthly What?

Podcasts

Organizing Ideas Podcast: Episode 20 with Jessica Schomberg Jessica Schomberg talks about their book, other readings they‚Äôve learned from, how workplace improvements for disabled folks will lead to better workplaces for everyone, about relationships and solidarity in library work. It‚Äôs a really engaging listen!

The Latino Card: Episode ‚Äî¬†Mask-ulinity Talking about different approaches people are taking to social distancing. Discusses ?Tommy Simmons? article at the Idaho Press, which talks about psychology of adhering to government guidelines. How wearing a mask is a signal to the world that COVID19 is a problem & we need to work together on addressing it. Masculinity and admitting vulnerability.

The Better Bozo: Episode 6 I wasn‚Äôt sure about listening to this whole episode for the first few minutes, since it sounded a little too much like listening in on a sporpsball conversation or general talk radio. But it ended up featuring a fascinating discussion about how privileged white guys can get better at asking themselves ‚Äúwho benefits by me staying silent at this moment?‚Äù, as well as how to apply organizing principles to help forward collective liberation. One portion that seems particularly relevant to library work is when the guest, Abraham Lateiner of Freedom Beyond!, mentions that it‚Äôs important to be attuned to both the macro and micro levels in a situation, as well as the tension between two poles. (Apparently polarity work is an organizing tool?) The main polarized tension he discusses is between challenge and affirmation.

He uses the example of how America has praised individual freedoms for so long that it‚Äôs become incredibly difficult to champion equitable outcomes. As I‚Äôm typing this, I can‚Äôt help but wonder what an ALA Office of Intellectual Responsibility would look like, or even an ALA Office of Intellectual Equity.

Articles

‚ÄúStarting Points‚Äù by Andrew Cooper was written for the Buddhist Peace Fellowship‚Äôs Turning Wheel magazine in 1993, on the second anniversary of the beating of Rodney King. Cooper explains, ‚ÄúThe question is not whether or not a community is ‚Äòracist‚Äô‚Äîthe question is how this racism operates.‚Äù He also quotes a psychiatrist‚Äôs explanation that ‚Äúin the human realm, the law of survival is not kill or be killed; it is define or be defined.‚Äù

I was living in Riverside and in high school for the King verdict and the uprisings, all of which were very much huge local news. Witnessing such a wanton failure of the legal system to produce justice profoundly influenced my understanding of our legal, social, economic, representational, and other systems. This article encapsulates a lot about those systems into surprisingly few words. As we still seek to improve upon these current systems, it‚Äôs an article well worth your time.
entry.summary: Organizing Ideas Podcast; The Latino Card; Tricycle Magazine; etc.

entry.title: Introducing Monthly Signal Boosts
entry.content:
What‚Äôs This About?

It‚Äôs pretty clear that my weekly assemblage posts aren‚Äôt particularly sustainable, at least at the moment. All the same, I want to get back to regular posts. With these I aim at boosting‚Äîsometimes also critiquing‚Äîthings that I appreciate.

Seeing Jessica Schomberg‚Äôs Monthly Reading Lists gave me the idea to do a monthly format.

We‚Äôll see where this goes!

How Will They Work?

I‚Äôm really good at reading and engaging widely‚Äîbut I‚Äôm not as great at keeping notes or forcing myself to reflect. So I‚Äôll experiment with the exact way I‚Äôll annotate or respond to what I mention in these.

I‚Äôm planning to start a post at the beginning of each month, then edit it throughout the month. So each will be a monthly log, pretty much, of stuff I want to amplify.

Is That It?

As I‚Äôm writing this introduction to these posts, I‚Äôm also working on putting together my dissertation qualifying exam lists. I‚Äôm intrigued by the ethos / approach of working in public, so I‚Äôm considering doing some sort of ‚Äúevergreen notes‚Äù‚Äîmost likely a set of pages that I continually edit as I refine ideas, definitions, connections, bibliographies, etc.

I‚Äôm not sure quite yet how that sort of note will live on my site, but again: we‚Äôll find out!
entry.summary: Monthly signal boosts will be short reflections on what I've read, listened to, watch, etc.

entry.title: ah, Carl, while you are not safe I am not safe

link.title: ah, Carl, while you are not safe I am not safe

entry.content:
Braiding Together a Few Strands of Thought

This post was prompted by a few things I saw on Mastodon and Twitter, plus having wanted to write something during LIS Mental Health Week for a few years now. I started drafting it as a short thread that brought in the social model of disability as a response to @chaotic_kat‚Äôs thread, then things sort of snowballed, and here we are!¬†

There‚Äôs a good chance I‚Äôll tweak this post further, but I want to share it before the last day of this year‚Äôs LIS Mental Health Week.

Some of our mental starting points include:

A.:

I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by austerity

— Sarah Osment (@sm_osment) February 22, 2020

In case that ‚ÄúHowl‚Äù allusion and the one in this post‚Äôs title don‚Äôt leap out at you, you might want to take the time to read it and its related ‚Äúfootnote‚Äù poem. Ideally read them aloud, as incandescently or woefully as you‚Äôd like.

B.:

Hey #ADHD #neurodiversesquad - I want to talk about how stigma, lack of education & support, and toxic masculinity has affected the the ADHD men in my life.

Thread

— #DREADPirate Kat B üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@chaotic_kat) September 5, 2019

I was diagnosed with ADHD by third or fourth grade, i.e. the later 1980s‚Äîand a bunch of that thread rings true for me. The bits that resonate most are years of hiding my diagnosis, avoiding meds/accommodations, later repeated bouts of shame/anxiety/depression, struggling to maintain friendships, etc. A lot of those negative things have been far worse for my cousins‚Äîand I believe my parents were a crucial difference in our experiences of all this because they gave me an early understanding of the social model of disability.

C.:
Meredith Wolfwater‚Äôs piece about a toxic workplace and how she‚Äôs worked to change herself since leaving it.

Meredith‚Äôs post reminds me a lot of the grad program I was in before taking the route of librarianship. I‚Äôm still not ready to write about my experiences in that program in much depth‚Äîbasically, it was fantastic, right up until it was the opposite. For now, it‚Äôll suffice to say that I‚Äôm not particularly good at reading internal politics‚Äîand that I was particularly unprepared to navigate having a couple of ‚Äúadvisors‚Äù who never gave advice about my project or substantive feedback on the contents of my project, only reminders that time was passing.

Social Model of Disability

When I said above that my parents helped mitigate the negative aspects of unmedicated ADHD, I mean that I üíØ lucked out by having special ed & d/Deaf educators as parents. The social model of disability influenced a lot of our talks, their emotional support, their ‚Äúhey, let‚Äôs see if this technique helps‚Äù encouragement, etc.

Although I don‚Äôt remember my parents using the phrase ‚Äúthe social model of disability,‚Äù they often talked about how deafness, blindness, and other perceptual impairments are not inherently barriers in and of themselves. Instead, these impairments become ‚Äúdisabilities‚Äù due to way we‚Äôve built social and material structures without accounting & preparing for these differences. The social and material exclusion people with impairments face becomes physical and social oppression.

Growing up around schools for the Deaf and Blind also meant that I was constantly around children and adults with very different abilities and ways of interacting than my own, getting to partake in their joy at dances and basketball games, where sound pressure and bass & drum vibrations helped everyone keep time or rally in support of their teams.

Bringing this back around to @chaotic_kat‚Äôs thread on toxic masculinity and what parents can do to help support children they expect to be neurodivergent, I believe my early internalization of the social model of disability profoundly lessened how much power ADHD stigma has had over my mental health. It meant that I never bought in to the notion that just ‚Äútrying harder‚Äù was an adequate or appropriate answer to things. I recognized that I was different, even if the 1980s & 1990s discourse around ADHD didn‚Äôt understand the broader range of how my differences would manifest.

It is what also primed me to see the structural/social aspects of toxic masculinity by early high school. Reading Fugazi lyrics, riot grrrl, Sassy & Dirt magazines, having a group of weirdo friends, etc also didn‚Äôt hurt, of course‚Äîand I also didn‚Äôt have those words for it yet. But between my own dad‚Äôs example of kindness and the cultural questioning of ‚Äútough guy‚Äù poses (‚Äúyour bulldog front‚Äù), it was increasingly clear that there are many ways of being a guy in the world‚Äîalthough many of the commons ways of doing so are toxic to others and oneself.

This social model made it way easier for me to get how race, gender, sexuality, class, etc often are linked to material structures of oppression, not just simple ‚Äúdifferences‚Äù without consequences or histories. Knowing that model isn‚Äôt sufficient, of course. And I now know first hand that it‚Äôs nowhere the same as actually taking meds, getting accommodations, etc. But knowing and internalizing that model leads more rapidly to solidarity, to coalitional thinking, to working to make more accessible websites, conferences, classrooms, workplaces, etc.

Sadly, the social model alone doesn‚Äôt overcome my deep Gen X knowledge that every institution‚Äîeven & especially ones you love, like that grad program‚Äîwill betray you, that any disclosure or first-hand advocacy can nudge that betrayal machinery into motion if it hasn‚Äôt already started.

But ‚Äúah, Carl, while you are not safe I am not safe‚Äù‚Äîso I need to be louder about my experiences, my joys, frustrations, and ways of being in the world, since that kind of coalition building across differences and identities is what will help dismantle the structures of oppression that continue diminishing and hurting neurodivergent folks, folks with mental health issues, folks from communities with racial, ethnic, or sexual identities that have been historically oppressed, etc. Collectively creating new identities like ‚Äúneurodiverse‚Äù is one way of negotiating and advocating for justice, both for ourselves & for others. This kind of coalitional work is indeed how we get free.

Poetry & Other Infrastructures of Support

Riverside Underground Poetry Organization in many ways got me through the depression of not being in school after undergrad, then through the anxiety of being back in grad school. An all ages open mic held in the basement of a coffeeshop owned by Darren (a gay Black man, whom I had the pleasure of interviewing for my high school newspaper the summer he opened the place), it‚Äôs one of the more radically inclusive communities I‚Äôve been part of‚Äîeven though I now realize the problems posed by the lack of physical accessibility to this kind of basement event.

The open mics offered an infrastructure for questioning society‚Äôs expectations and boundaries, a platform for performing multiple facets of your being in the span of three pieces or 10 minutes, whichever came first. That community carried me and others through quite a few years of ups and downs, heartbreaks and breakdowns and elations and achievements. I didn‚Äôt realize how much the loss of that community would affect me when I followed a professor‚Äôs recommendation to uproot myself and move across the country for a different program‚ÄîI figured that something akin to that simply must exist in other towns, since Southern California dumps on Riverside and the greater Inland Empire constantly for being a cultural backwater.

Fred Moten & Stefano Harney write a lot about study in their book The Undercommons: Fugitive Planning and Black Study. I‚Äôll readily admit that I‚Äôm still figuring out what they mean by study, by debt, and by many of the other terms in that book.¬†But to the extent I feel I understand ‚Äústudy‚Äù as a mode of collective questioning and relating to others outside of individuating institutions like academia, those open mic nights and the group of us who milled about and asked questions, shared drinks and embraces and tears and pitched in for gas and for rent, who carried each other through hard times and cheered at each others‚Äô achievements and performances‚Ä¶¬†that‚Äôs a model for questioning our current world and finding ways toward a better one.

This post doesn‚Äôt have a tidy conclusion‚Äîand I‚Äôm not sure it should.

I‚Äôm mostly just giving thanks and expressing solidarity with the #NeurodiverseSquad folks, with the LIS Mental Health Week people, with #critlib, and with the other online communities I learn from constantly. Although we‚Äôre distributed across the internet instead of sitting on the ground in a basement, these communities have become part of who I think with and for, who provide me much-needed models for subverting the status quo, for opening up new mental, physical, social, and technical spaces of possibility.

Thank you.
entry.summary: The social model of disability offers insights into society, differences, and oppressive structures beyond disability.

entry.title: ALA Annual 2018: My Schedule, Our Notes

link.title: ALA Annual 2018: My Schedule, Our Notes

entry.content:
#ALAAC2018

I haven‚Äôt been to an Annual ALA Conference yet, so it‚Äôll be interesting to see how my attention can hold up to meeting so many people and hearing so many ideas. I‚Äôve been to a number of smaller conferences, but nothing on this scale.

Building from the Critical ALA Annual 2018 list of ‚Äúsessions of possible interest to critical library workers‚Äù made by Eamon Tewell and others, here‚Äôs a schedule of where I intend to be while in NOLA. I‚Äôll do my best to update this throughout the week, so we can try to meet up if you‚Äôd like. Messaging me on Mastodon or Twitter would be great ways to get in touch.

I‚Äôll do my best to always have an In the Library with the Lead Pipe button on my backpack or lanyard to make it easier to spot me. Please feel free to chat about the journal‚Äôs submission or open peer review processes, talk about ideas you have, or anything else. I‚Äôll bring a few buttons with the journal logo‚Äôs to give away as well.

I‚Äôll probably also bring a small number of earplugs. So if you plan to go out dancing or if you see me out somewhere loud, ask and I might have some for you & your ears.

Group Note-taking > Live Tweeting

There‚Äôs a growing practice of shared note-taking at unconferences and conferences, like at CLAPS2016 and at the #critlib Unconference 2017 in Baltimore. Let‚Äôs keep that going and try using more privacy-respecting platforms this time around.

If you‚Äôre interested in helping take group notes‚Äîwhich seem like a more hospitable format than live tweeting for many of us‚ÄîI‚Äôm planning to make publicly-editable Etherpad notes hosted at RiseUp. It‚Äôll be like shared Google Docs, only on a platform that helps avoid Google‚Äôs many privacy-destroying tentacles. :octopus: :thumbsdown:

My plan is to:

  • [x] make a pad for each session I'll attend @done
  • [x] give each pad a 1 year lifespan (which anyone can do as they create a pad) @done
  • [x] link to those pads here @done
  • ultimately move our collectively-written notes somewhere else to be determined, such as my site or maybe something like a Sandstorm.io instance for library workers and/or other folks interested in #critlib-type things.1

If you can think of a better process or make other pads/notes that you want added to shared list, let me know on Mastodon or Twitter!

Lastly, please: if there‚Äôs a microphone, always use the microphone.

My Schedule

Thursday

I‚Äôm flying in today‚Äîand I wish I could be listening to KEXP‚Äôs breakdown of Public Enemy‚Äôs It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back while in flight. Hopefully they record it or at least spell out the playlist somewhere. Fear of a Black Planet was much more formative for me but I‚Äôd love to learn anything I could about the Bomb Squad‚Äôs production process for any of their albums.

I might be down to meet up for vegetarian/vegan food, coffee, or other stuff this evening. Let me know!

Friday

In the morning & early afternoon I‚Äôll be exploring NOLA and the convention center.

1:00p‚Äì2:00pm:
(NMRT) Annual Conference Orientation
etherpad notes

4:00pm‚Äì5:30pm:
Opening General Session featuring Michelle Obama
etherpad notes

5:30pm‚Äì6:30pm:
Meet the Authors: Mariko Tamaki and Shea Fontana (most likely)

Saturday

9:00am‚Äì10:00am:
Making the Framework Work: Adapting the ACRL Framework for Information Literacy in Community College Library Instruction
etherpad notes

10:30am‚Äì11:30am:
Student Learning and Information Literacy Committee Discussion Forum
etherpad notes

1:00pm‚Äì2:30pm:
(LIRT) Moving Beyond the Threshold: Next Steps in Critical Information Literacy
etherpad notes

2:30pm‚Äì3:30pm:
Building Inclusion: How Can Research Instruction at Two-Year Colleges Help Students Successfully Transition to the University?
etherpad notes

4:00pm‚Äì5:00pm:
New Librarians on the Block: Early Career Librarianship, Management, and Leadership
etherpad notes

Sunday

9:00am‚Äì10:00am:
High Impact Librarianship: A Showcase of Collaborative and Experiential Learning Initiatives
etherpad notes

10:30am‚Äì11:30am:
Whiteness in LIS: Tracing its Impact, Mapping Resistance
etherpad notes

12:00pm‚Äì1:00pm:
In the Library in the Lead Pipe meet up in the Networking Uncommons

2:30pm‚Äì3:30pm:
Breaking Below the Surface of Racism, Whiteness, and Implicit Bias
etherpad notes

4:00pm‚Äì5:00pm:
Bridging the Gap: Supporting Subject Liaisons to Become Ambassadors for Digital Scholarship in Academic Libraries
etherpad notes
OR
Neutrality and Its Discontents: Exploring the Ethics of Librarianship in a Partisan World
etherpad notes
OR MORE LIKELY
4:30om‚Äì5:30pm:
Progressive Librarians Guild Meeting

6:00pm‚Äì8:00pm:
GLBT Round Table Social
OR
DSS Social (ACRL DSS)

8:00pm‚Äì??:
Que(e)ry at ALA New Orleans

Monday

9:00am‚Äì10:00am:
Evidence Based Library and Information Practice is‚Ä¶
etherpad link

10:30am‚Äì11:30am:
Buried in a ‚ÄúDying‚Äù Field: Pessimism, Uncertain Futures, and the LIS job search
etherpad link
OR
When to Speak Up, When to Listen: Allyship, Race, and Communication in the Academic Library
etherpad link
OR
Open Education Resources (OER): Where Libraries Are and Where We are Going
etherpad link

1:00pm‚Äì2:00pm:
Effort, Education, Knowledge, Skill and Teaching Recognized: The READ (Reference Effort Assessment Data) Scale at work in Academic, Public & Special Libraries
etherpad link

4:00pm‚Äì5:00pm:
A Library for Everyone: Community Centered Design to Promote Inclusive Librarianship
etherpad link

Tuesday

10:00am‚Äì11:30am:
Closing General Session featuring Viola Davis
etherpad link

  1. Making a Sandstorm instance is kind of pie-in-the-sky as a goal for me at the moment, but I can definitely put the notes on my blog at minimum. If you‚Äôre interested in helping with a Sandstorm instance for library workers, let‚Äôs talk!¬†↩
entry.summary: Where I intend to be for ALAAC2018 and how I think we can make group notes.

entry.title: WA 2017 Week 09: Badges, Type, BibTeX
entry.content:
Weekly Whaaa‚Ä¶?

Emily Ford‚Äôs ‚ÄúTo badge or not to badge? From ‚Äòyes‚Äô to ‚Äònever again‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúTo badge or not to badge? From ‚Äòyes‚Äô to ‚Äònever again‚Äô‚Äù

I really like this article and appreciate Emily Ford‚Äôs perspective here. Oddly enough, we‚Äôve gone ahead with a variant of badging at my college just this semester. It‚Äôs really more about flipping the content than a ‚Äúbadging‚Äù system, and I think we‚Äôre doing it in a way that avoids the pitfalls she‚Äôs laid out nicely in this article. At least, I hope we are. We‚Äôre doing assessment, so we‚Äôll find out!

Pablo Stanley‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Type Snob‚Äù

The Type Snob (and how to turn into one)

I‚Äôm not exactly pro-snob, but I am staunchly in favor of a well-made explainer.

VukanJ‚Äôs ‚Äúbibtex-helper‚Äù for Atom

Ever since I first read Dennis Tenen and Grant Wythoff‚Äôs Sustainable Authorship in Plain Text using Pandoc and Markdown lesson at The Programming Historian, I‚Äôve been into the idea of using Pandoc and BibTeX. I haven‚Äôt done so extensively‚Äîjust for the last semester of library school, so far.

However, I really like the idea of using simplified citekeys, so I‚Äôm putting together a system around this now, as I‚Äôm in the middle of a writing project that uses a lot of articles I‚Äôm highly likely to use again in the future.

Which is where VukanJ‚Äôs bibtext-helper comes in. I‚Äôve taken to using the Atom editor whenever I can, and VukanJ‚Äôs tool is basically a set of snippets I can invoke by typing the citation style (e.g. @inproceedings or @article), which prompts Atom to expand the snippet into a citation template with all the appropriate fields for that type of citation. At first I couldn‚Äôt figure out how to add it to Atom, since VukanJ‚Äôs documentation is‚Ä¶let‚Äôs say ‚Äúlight.‚Äù I eventually just hit select-all on this file, copied everything, then pasted it into my snippets.cson file in Atom. At first it didn‚Äôt work, so I changed the '.text.bibtex' in line 1 to '.text.md'. Now it sings! I did alter a few things‚Äîspecifically adding @crossref = {} to the @inbook, @incollection, @inproceedings, and @inreference snippets, as Nelson H. F. Beebe‚Äôs super-helpful guide suggests. I also added address = {} to the relevant snippets.

For the last few things I‚Äôve written, I used Zotero to collate the info and then Bibdesk to put the citation into my writing. But I profoundly didn‚Äôt like how that combination wouldn‚Äôt let me change the citekey. Numbers and time aren‚Äôt intrinsically meaningful to my mind, so I‚Äôd much rather cite something as @hall_local_and_global than @hall_1989a. I also didn‚Äôt like how the Zotero + Bibdesk citations would seem to arbitrarily decide to force capitalization.

I‚Äôm thinking I might put up my main bibliography file on Github somewhere, either as part of this site or somewhere else. It‚Äôd be nice to be able to refer to those citekeys from anywhere I might be writing or making reading notes. But for now‚Äîactually almost a month after I first wrote the paragraphs above‚ÄîI‚Äôm just going to mention this as one the next citation approach I‚Äôm exploring.
entry.summary: Briefly linking to Emily Ford's article about badges, a short reference about using type on the web, and getting going with a bibliography tool.

entry.title: WA 2017 Week 01: Journaling, Pedagogy, and Advocating for our Patrons

link.title: WA 2017 Week 01: Journaling, Pedagogy, and Advocating for our Patrons

entry.content:
Weekly Whaaa‚Ä¶?

Craig Eley‚Äôs Jekyll logbook theme

Perhaps it was due to participating in the #critlib chat on reflection, moderated by Lisa Hubbell? Perhaps it was because I miss using DayOne, which I slowly abandoned after they changed how they sync the files? Perhaps it‚Äôs just that I‚Äôve gotten really used to using Jekyll, and this is another interesting use of that familiar technology?

In any event, I started using Craig Eley‚Äôs ‚ÄúTrophy Logbook‚Äù theme for Jekyll over the holidays and really appreciate it so far. I even submitted My First Pull Request‚Ñ¢, helping organize the tags alphabetically with Liquid rather than strictly chronologically. (I‚Äôm going to try to help figure out how to sort by tags frequency, but that‚Äôs on the back-burner for probably at least another week.)

If you‚Äôd like to try journaling with it‚Äîor if you‚Äôd just like to give Jekyll a try without your first attempt being public‚ÄîEley‚Äôs theme works quite well. Craig explains in his Medium post that it‚Äôs designed to use tags to track people‚Äôs name and categories to track places. For my own use, I‚Äôm doing that, but also tracking regular topic tags with the simple blunt strategy of adding 0- before the tag, so they‚Äôre all sorted prior to the names. So instead of just writing meta in the tag field, I‚Äôm writing 0-meta. I don‚Äôt track physical locations very often, so I‚Äôm mostly using categories to track the media I watch or read. I‚Äôve started putting some reading notes in there as well. I‚Äôve been hankering for a place to put reading notes, and having the option of using both the work‚Äôs title and topic tags seems like a very promising set-up for them.

This theme uses Jekyll plugins that make it incompatible with Github Pages‚Äînot a bad thing, unless you‚Äôre exhibitionist enough to want your journal rendered publicly. If you want a private place to store your journal and perhaps write to it from a different device than your computer, GitLab lets you have private repos for free.

Bonnie Stuart‚Äôs posts on Antigonish

Bonnie Stewart‚Äôs last two articles, ‚Äútemporarily embarrassed millionaires‚Äù and ‚ÄúAntigonish 2.0‚Äîthe plan‚Äù, are giving me some hope and optimism about how librarians and other educators can advocate for everyone in our communities in the next few years.

Bryan Alexander‚Äôs We Make the Path by Walking group read

The first of Bonnie Stewart‚Äôs two above articles mentions We Make the Road by Walking, a book by Myles Horton and Paulo Freire. If you haven‚Äôt already notice how much of a touchstone Freire has become among instruction librarians, Joshua F. Beatty presented an excellent paper at the 2015 CAPAL conference, which he has open-access here.

Bryan Alexander up some of the activities on an online group read of We Make the Road by Walking in ‚ÄúReading Horton and Freire in 2017‚Äù. I‚Äôm going to have a busy semester with a lot of reading, but I‚Äôm aiming to read this book as well. It‚Äôs important to not just acknowledge, but also learn from, histories of what works domestically. Horton‚Äôs Highlander Folk School certainly has a history to learn from.

Meredith Farkas‚Äô ‚ÄúNever Neutral: Critical librarianship and technology‚Äù

It‚Äôs great to see that Meredith Farkas‚Äô article on the impossibility of neutrality and the harm perpetuated by failing to advocate for our patrons is reading the readers of American Libraries Magazine.

It‚Äôs short and worth reading in its entirety. Here are a couple excellent quotes that resonate strongly with my week-to-week work:

Librarians may not be able to change Google or Facebook, but we can educate our patrons and support the development of the critical-thinking skills they need to navigate an often-biased online world. We can empower our patrons when we help them critically evaluate information and teach them about bias in search engines, social media, and publishing.

We are not doing our job if we remain neutral when it comes to library technologies. Accepting many of the technologies available to support our missions means accepting technologies that are biased, not accessible, not protective of the privacy of our users, and not easily usable by some of our patrons. A commitment to social justice is a commitment to equal access, which is at the heart of our professional values. We are not being neutral when we advocate for our patrons, but we are being good librarians.
entry.summary: Can I make routinely time for these round-up posts this semester? Let's find out, shall we? Links about journaling, pedagogy, and advocating for our patrons.

entry.title: Critical Reflection #critlib chat
entry.content:
Here‚Äôs a post in preparation for the ‚ÄúCritical Reflection‚Äù #critlib chat moderated by Lisa Hubbell.

Lisa Hubbell‚Äôs commitment to making this chat about critical reflection more accessible to people for whom Twitter isn‚Äôt optimal inspired me enough to want to do a ‚Äúseeding‚Äù blog post of my own. The topic itself seems to beg for a different kind of engagement. I‚Äôve got a few different facets of ‚Äúreflection‚Äù in mind, so I‚Äôll try to address all of them here.

Tools for Thinking

Prompts work well for me, as do other tools for thinking.

The most basic of these prompts was drilled into me while I was on high school newspaper, if not earlier: the old, reliable ‚Äúwho, what, when, where, why, and how?‚Äù questions.

Here‚Äôs a few more that I believe help nuance those and make our answers more critically reflective:1

  • For whom is this accurate, in what ways, and under what conditions?
  • Who does this obscure?
  • Whose participation is left out?
  • Does this way of thinking frame people as passive or active?
  • How is this useful? What does it help us do in the world?

David Seah‚Äôs various productivity tools profoundly help reinforce a practice of reflection. Unlike a lot of people who write about productivity, his site and tools don‚Äôt trip my spidey sense for boosterism or selling things. He gives the documents away as free downloads! (He does sell pre-printed ones as well.) Instead, between his explanations of the various tools and his own blog about things like his ‚Äúgroundhog resolutions‚Äù, he seems very committed to the idea that review is a (maybe the?) path to progress.

I like Seah‚Äôs phrase ‚Äútools for thinking‚Äù enough that it‚Äôs what I call most of the relevant library handouts I make at my library: simple templates for expanding & narrowing search terms, for brainstorming keywords, that kind of thing.

My Actual Practice

For readings, I take lots of marginal notes. This semester I read Casey Boyle‚Äôs ‚Ä¶something like a reading ethics‚Ä¶, and I intend to start doing something along those lines from here on out.

My reading notes‚Äîand all of my notes, really‚Äîare plain text, in Markdown format, and stored in Dropbox. That way I can always sync them between whatever computer or device I‚Äôm using. I usually use Atom on my laptop or at work, plus Editorial on my phone.

Plain text synced through Dropbox means that I don‚Äôt have to fret about leaving a notebook filled in my insights somewhere. I profoundly enjoy writing by hand, but I don‚Äôt enjoy the anxiety that builds up the more I have in a notebook and nowhere else. When I want to go back and somehow do revisions on earlier ideas in plain text, I‚Äôll usually use Critic Markup for most of my jotting-ideas-down writing, or much more rarely I‚Äôll track changes for more formal writing through Git.

I also have a sort of bullet journal with plain text files for each month, with the idea that I‚Äôll go back and do some review every night as well as again on weekends. It helps, but I certainly don‚Äôt do it as consistently as I‚Äôd like.

The Pomodoro technique (and time-blocking more generally) also sometimes helps when I need extra push to focus on something that I know I also want to examine critically. Pomodoros seem to give me permission to toggle between the ‚Äúmake stuff!‚Äù and ‚Äúwait, what‚Äôs this leading toward?‚Äù habits of mind. Beyond just each 30 minute cycle (25 minutes of GO!!!!!, 5 minutes reflection), the broader technique also invites more substantive reflection every few hours and at the beginning & end of the day. I‚Äôm not great with experiencing time, and therefore really not great at estimating time. Since pomodoros turn nicely into time tracking, it‚Äôs a practice with many interlocking benefits.2

My Desired Practice

Since Lisa Hubbell‚Äôs second ‚Äúseeding‚Äù post for this critlib chat delves into broader teachings and reflective practices, I‚Äôll mention that Buddhist thought has worked well for me since about high school. I wouldn‚Äôt claim to be a practicing Buddhist and don‚Äôt really identify as one, just as sort of a long-time beginner or appreciator; I don‚Äôt go to a regular meeting place, don‚Äôt have a consistent meditation practice, and couldn‚Äôt recall the details of the noble eightfold path or any other fundamental precepts off the top of my head. All the same, Buddhist teachings around liberation, loving kindness, and mindfulness more than merely resonate with me. They help me make sense of the world. They work for me, and they‚Äôve worked for other people I care about deeply.

I‚Äôve found helpful things in writings by bell hooks (that‚Äôs to her posts at Lion‚Äôs Roar magazine/website, although my introduction to her Buddhism was the ‚ÄúAgent of Change‚Äù article for which Tricycle occasionally lifts its paywall), Shunryu Suzuki‚Äôs Zen Mind, Beginner‚Äôs Mind, Brad Warner‚Äôs Hardcore Zen, and Chade-Meng Tan‚Äôs endearingly self-deprecating Search Inside Yourself.3

Years ago, when I desperately needed to hear something along its lines, the Back to Work ‚ÄúThe Second Arrow‚Äù episode on ADD, Buddhism, and mindfulness was profoundly helpful, too.

For a critlib audience? I really, really recommend listening to this ‚ÄúTalking Race, Love, and Liberation‚Äù episode of the Buddhist Geeks podcast.4 The dialog between the host & Reverend angel Kyodo williams captures the sort of liberation-seeking, loving kindness practice that I‚Äôm working toward making my own critical reflective practice.

  1. I don‚Äôt recall seeing these anywhere in particular; they‚Äôre sort of a distillation of what I‚Äôve picked up from various types of what I consider ‚Äúcritical theory,‚Äù ranging from Cultural Studies to various types of activism to rhetorical analysis.¬†↩

  2. If you want to get next-level geeky with this, Ugo Landini‚Äôs Pomodoro app for Mac can sync up with Growl notifications and then even to your phone with Prowl notifications. Time‚Äôs passage can follow you even when you wander away from your keyboard, as long as you carry your phone with you. If you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôll be humbled by how rapidly & repeatedly your monkey mind runs away from your intentions.¬†↩

  3. I feel I‚Äôm obligated to also gesture toward whatever second-hand Alan Watts books I read back in high school, but I suspect they‚Äôd strike me as pretty Orientalist if I re-read them now. Choose your own adventure with those. Looking at titles & cover images, it probably included The Way of Zen and This is It.¬†↩

  4. It has enough Buddhist terminology that I occasionally felt more like an eavesdropper than a listener, but I kind of feel like that‚Äôs an especially productive approach to this topic. It‚Äôs good practice to sit with not being centered by a conversation.¬†↩
entry.summary: Critical reflection questions I ask myself and tools I find useful.

entry.title: WA 2016 Week 32: Lots of Linkage; Comments Have Arrived

link.title: WA 2016 Week 32: Lots of Linkage; Comments Have Arrived

entry.content:
Weekly Whaaa‚Ä¶?

Lots of Linkage

Here‚Äôs a handful of links that I either shared or meant to share on Twitter:

Rachael Neu linked to Richard Van Heertum‚Äôs ‚ÄúHow Objective is Objectivity?‚Äù article in UCLA InterActions journal recently in a list-serv. I‚Äôm eagerly awaiting reading that article, but in the meanwhile wanted to share the link to the InterActions overall. It looks like a great, open access, peer-reviewed LIS and education publication that focuses on information studies, not strictly information science. In other words, it‚Äôs very much up my alley!

Speaking of open access, I was very intrigued by Archambault, C√¥t√©, Struck, and Voorons‚Äô note Research Impact of Paywalled versus Open Access Papers.

I saw that the Conference Proceedings of JITP 2010: The Politics of Open Source is online and open access. I found that while searching for a copy of John Sullivan‚Äôs ‚ÄúFree, Open Source Software Advocacy as a Social Justice Movement: The Discourse of Digital Rights in the 21st Century‚Äù article, which I‚Äôm still very much looking forward to reading.

Library Juice Press recently posted an interview with Dr. Annie Downey, author of Critical Information Literacy. It‚Äôs a great read and makes me look forward to getting my grubby paws my strenuously professional hands on a copy of the book that I can annotate for my very own!

Here‚Äôs a fun bread closing taxonomy. I hope to eventually work it into our information literacy for the sciences somehow.

Tara Robertson and Jenna Freedman moderated a #critlib Twitter conversation on the ethics of digitization. I wasn‚Äôt able to participate directly (only chiming in with a couple half-formed thoughts well afterward) but it looked great.

Comments Have Arrived

I‚Äôve long wanted to add comments to the site without making people sign up for yet another service, as is required by most ways of adding comments to static sites (i.e. those made with Jekyll and similar site generators). So I was super excited when I saw that Michael Rose had added Staticman to the newest version of the Minimal Mistakes theme! The present site is still running on a much older version, but I managed to get the comments working and he was kind enough to help me figure out how to make them display properly.

You‚Äôre very welcome to submit a comment. I will of course moderate them, which Staticman cleverly allows by making use of GitHub‚Äôs branching feature. I‚Äôm excited by the prospect of this site becoming more collegial and interactive! 1

  1. Simultaneously, I‚Äôm not above wielding the moderation hammer with all the wanton glee of the Designers Republic‚Äôs Sissy. Cheers!¬†↩
entry.summary: Many open access links plus excitement about adding comments to the site.
